greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = max { k | gcd(n, k) = k and gcd(k, 6) = 1 }.
comment: Bennett, Filaseta, & Trifonov show that if n > 8 then a(n^2 + n) > n^0.285. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, May 21 2014
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
M. A. Bennett, M. Filaseta, and O. Trifonov, On the factorization of consecutive integers, J. Reine Angew. Math. 629 (2009), pp. 171-200.
formula: Multiplicative with a(2^e)=1, a(3^e)=1, a(p^e)=p^e, p>3. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Nov 02 2001
a(1)=1; then a(2n)=a(n), a(2n+1)=a((2n+1)/3) if 2n+1 is divisible by 3, a(2n+1)=2n+1 otherwise. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jun 04 2007
mathematica: f[n_] := Times @@ (First@#^Last@# & /@ Select[FactorInteger@n, First@# != 2 && First@# != 3 &]); Array[f, 81] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Aug 18 2006 *)
program: (PARI) a(n)=n\gcd(n,6^n) \\ Not very efficient, but simple. _Stanislav Sykora_, Feb 08 2016
(MAGMA) [n div Gcd(n, 6^n): n in [1..100]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Feb 09 2016
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 29 2001
